awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Reinforcement learning based adaptive optimal control of powered knee prosthesis for human users in real life
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research aims at designing robust, real time learning controllers for powered lower limb prosthesis worn by above-knee amputees. It centers on adaptive optimal tuning of prosthetic knee joint impedance parameters with an ultimate goal of achieving human-prosthesis symbiosis. Current state-of-the-art approaches rely on a predetermined collection of knee joint impedance parameters, resulted from tedious manual tuning in a clinic. In addition to a lack of adaptability to different users, current impedance controls do not adapt to different use environments. One of the key design challenge is due to the constant interaction between the human user and the robotic leg. As such, advanced robotics including those employing latest artificial intelligence technologies, control system theory and design, and existing biomechanics based controls cannot meet the needs of real time learning control of a powered prosthetic leg in a human-prosthesis system. Given the nature of the problem, reinforcement learning based adaptive optimal control, also referred to as adaptive dynamic programming (ADP), holds great promise to delivering the next generation of prosthesis control solutions. 

Intellectual Merit: The design challenge requires innovative approaches of real time reinforcement learning control. The learning controller has to be designed without knowing an explicit dynamic system model describing the human-prosthesis system, while assuring human user safety and system stability, and being scalable and adaptable to different users and use conditions. Putting it all together, the success of this project will be an important milestone for machine learning, control engineering, and rehabilitation engineering. 

Broader Impacts: This research has a direct impact on improving the lives of above-knee amputees. Also of great societal impact is the potential of reducing health care cost. New knowledge gained from human-robot interaction will not only aid amputees but also stroke patients who use exoskeleton as assistive devices. The proposed research will also benefit several research communities such as wearable robots, machine learning, and rehabilitation to develop new technologies addressing real applications. To excite and educate future leaders and researchers in science and engineering, the project will provide an opportunity for integration of our research work into graduate education and postdoc training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to develop robust, real-time reinforcement learning (RL) control for powered knee prosthesis. The problem entails control of a wearable robot to enable continuous and stable walking of the user. This project is uniquely challenging due to the interacting human and robot controls over the robotic knee while it is difficult to model the interacting dynamics between the two agents. Thus, innovative solution approaches are needed as existing methods are not readily applicable.

Through the project period, as the first group to tackle the challenge, we have pioneered several reinforcement learning control designs based on innovative conceptualization of the problem that involves a human in the loop. Our solution approaches are theoretically sound, systematically and comprehensively evaluated via simulations, and experimentally tested on human subjects including amputee subjects.

We successfully addressed technical challenges by developing reinforcement learning control designs for the applications under consideration. We developed our results with the following design requirements/constraints in mind. (1) The learning controller has to be data- and time-efficient. It can take full advantage of past experience while is able to adapt in real time as needed within safe human response time frame. (2) A prosthesis user can walk naturally and feel comfortable by employing realistic design goals and walking performance measures as global control feedback (or reinforcement signal) in the learning controller design.

Our results represent the state-of-the-art (SOTA). We are the first to show feasibility and potential of automatically adapting robotic prosthesis control to meet individual user’s needs and physical condition changes. Our results have been published in top AI and reinforcement learning control venues.

 Our research provides not only pioneering new approaches to the design practice of wearable lower limb robots, but also new insights that possibly lead to broader applications of physical human-robot interaction. We believe that the success of this project is an important milestone for AI/machine learning and control engineering in terms of how AI can help improve the quality of life for people with locomotion impairment.

 This project is collaborative and inter-disciplinary. It involves two labs at Arizona State University and North Carolina State University. The project has allowed the team to cross train nine graduate students, four of whom are at Arizona State University, among whom three successfully completed their PhD degree program. Ph.D. students from both labs completed their training and have since moved on their academic career path or started working in high-tech, R&D companies. In addition, the outreach activities in this project focused on promoting STEM and human-centered computing to undergraduate students and graduate students alike, especially those from STEM underrepresented groups. The PIs have disseminated their results through multiple venues including high quality journal and conference paper publications, giving invited talks at conferences/workshops and research institutions.
